title: Resistive forces - comparing two falling toys

content.question: During a classroom experiment, a small toy of mass <math alttext="m sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math> is dropped and experiences a resistive force of magnitude <math alttext="F sub S equals k sub 0, end sub, times v squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>S</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math> while falling, where <math alttext="k sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> is a constant and <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> is the toyâ€™s speed. It is then determined that a second, larger toy of mass <math alttext="4 m sub T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>T</mi></msub></math> experiences a greater resistive force of magnitude <math alttext="F sub L equals 9 F sub S, which equals 9 k sub 0, end sub, times v squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>L</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>S</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> while falling. What is the ratio of the terminal speed of the larger toy to the terminal speed of the smaller toy?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
